name: Hospice Doctor
shortText: The Hospice Doctor oversees care and prescribes medication for pain.
longText: The hospice doctor can be someone's primary care physician or possibly the Hospice medical director.

name: Nurse
shortText: Visits at least every two weeks to manage symptoms and refine treatments.
longText: Nurses visit based on based on someone's need and are typically the case managers, that is someone who coordinates much of what is needed.

name: Aide
shortText: Visits several days a week to help with basic home tasks.
longText: The aid typically visits to do personal care tasks such as bathing and or grooming.  Their stay is typically an hour or two.

name: Social Worker
shortText: Speaks to the family and person receiving hospice about family issues.
longText: The social worker helps with logistics  and side issues. They also help in planning for the future and coordinating care schedules.

name: Chaplain
shortText: Provides spiritual support, they are for people of any faith.
longText: Chaplains help organize religious rites that someone requests and getting them in contact with another of their own faith tradition. Chaplains can also be very good counselors to speak about issues with.

name: Volunteer
shortText: Assists with groceries, gardening, or other small tasks.
longText: Volunteers can be requested to help with tasks such as shopping, gardening or keeping watch of the person signed onto hospice while the caregiver is away.

name: Therapist
shortText: Someone on hospice receives help from a variety of therapists.
longText: Therapists range from physical therapists, dieticians, speech-language  pathologists, and other services.

name: Grief Counselor
longText: Grief Counselors provide care to both the person signed onto hospice, their family members, and their loved ones who may be dealing with issues of grief.  This service is given during and after the time of hospice.
